div.head: How we genderized forenames
div.p: We want to know the gender-distribution amongst the participants/authors of the TEI conference 2016. But since we have not asked the contributors about their gender, we are confronted with a lack of data. But since we have tagged the author's forenames it shouldn't be too hard to deduce the person's gender from the person's name. Or to be more precise, to deduce the gender which a name is mostly associated with. Just to be clear, we are not making guesses about the gender of the authors. We are making guesses about the gender of the names of the authors.

Making guess about the gender of a forename is quite easy if you can base your guesses upon some empirical evidence. Evidence like list of names of persons which declared their gender. We started with such a list provided by Mark Kantrowitz, used e.g. in the NLTK package. Unfortunately there is hardly any documentation about deciding which name matches which gender. Therefore we looked for another resource and found genderizo.io, a web service to determine the gender of a first name. They at least claim they assembled their data from social network profiles and they provide an API to their data, so we went with them.

Finding an adequate dataset was hard, using it was easy by writing a simple xQuery script which
iterates over all forename-elements,
takes the text node of each element,
builds a URL out of it,
sending a GET-request to the genderizo.io-API,
parses the response,
and adds the parsed response in form of a type attribute to the forename attribute.
The only slightly annoying thing was the 1000-request-per-day-for-free-limit set up by genderizo.io, which forced us to split this script in parts.

div.head: What we did then
div.p: Having our data enriched, the fun part starts. First we wanted to know the gender distribution amongst the author's forenames. This question was answered by gender-distribution.xql. A script which also feeds the matching visualization.

We also wanted to know for each abstracts to which gender the authors forenames are related to. This question could be answerd with the script text-gender.xql. And this script feeds also its matching visualization.
